This page features the Cyrillic alphabet.]] '''Ot''' ({{unicode|Ѿ ѿ}}; italics: <span style="font-family: times, Times New Roman, serif; font-size: larger">''{{unicode|Ѿ ѿ}}''</span>) is a letter of the [[early Cyrillic alphabet]]. Though it originated as a [[ligature (typography)|ligature]] of the letters [[Omega (Cyrillic)|Omega]] ({{unicode|Ѡ ѡ}}) and [[Te (Cyrillic)|Te]] (Т т), it functions as a discrete letter of the alphabet, placed between х and ц.<ref>Note that Ivan Fedorov’s alphabet does not include ѡ (though it does include ѽ). This is because it does include ѻ, which was considered orthographically equivalent; one may compare the alphabet from [[Spiridon Sobol|Spiridon Sobol’s]] abecedarium of 1631, which has ѡ where Ivan Fedorov has ѻ.</ref> This can be seen in the first printed Cyrillic abecedarium (illustrated), and continues in modern usage.<ref>Иеромонах Алипий, Грамматика церковно-славянского языка, Saint Petersburg, 1997, p. 17</ref> Ot is used in [[Church Slavonic]] to represent the preposition отъ 'from' and prefix от-. It does not stand for this sequence of letters in any other context, nor can the sequence от be substituted for it where it does occur. It is used with a similar purpose in mediaeval manuscripts of other [[Slavic languages|Slavonic]] languages written with the Cyrillic alphabet. In printed books ѿ is often used in preference to (ѡ҃) for the numeral 800. ==Computing codes== {{charmap |047E|name1=Cyrillic Capital Letter Ot |047F|name2=Cyrillic Small Letter Ot }} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Cyrillic ligatures]]
